'''Rûm''' was the name of a great and ancient city of [[Men]] in the [[Great Lands]], according to the early version of the [[legendarium]] in ''[[The Book of Lost Tales]]''.<ref name=Rum>{{LT2|VIb}}, p. 315</ref> It was identified with the city of [[wikipedia:Rome|Rome]],<ref>{{LT2|Index}}, p. 378</ref> being mentioned by [[Littleheart]] in the tale of ''[[The Fall of Gondolin (chapter)|the Fall of Gondolin]]'', where he described the [[Fall of Gondolin|sack]] of [[Gondolin]] as being even worse than many that befell Rûm, the greatest city of Men.<ref>{{LT2|III}}, p. 196</ref>

Its inhabitants were known as the '''''Rúmhoth''''', who were one of the peoples who [[Wikipedia:Roman conquest of Britain|invaded]] [[Tol Eressëa]] and expelled the [[Elves]] from it, not even believing they existed.<ref>{{LT2|VI}}, outline '''14''', p. 294; outline '''20''', p. 304; outline '''22''', p. 306</ref>

In one of the ''[[Early Runic Documents]]'', contemporary with ''The Book of Lost Tales'', there is also a mention of the [[wikipedia:Roman people|Romans]] as being the "slayers and faders of the fairies".<ref>{{PE|15}}, "[[Early Runic Documents]]", ''ER1d: Fourth page'', p. 96</ref>

== Etymology ==
The name ''Rûm'' is in [[Gnomish]], clearly an [[Sindarization|adaptation]] of Latin "Roma", the name used by both Elves and Men.

The Elves alone called it '''''Magbar'''''.<ref name=Rum/>

''Rúmhoth'', the name of its inhabitants, is composed of ''Rûm'' + ''[[Hoth (Gnomish word)|hoth]]'' ("folk, people").<ref>{{webcite|author=[[Paul Strack]]|articleurl=http://eldamo.org/content/words/word-2443818421.html|articlename=G. ''Rúmhoth'' coll.|website=Eldamo|accessed=1 May 2022}}</ref>
